p: Yefim Haim Michlin is a Senior Researcher in Quality Assurance and Reliability at the Technion. He obtained the Ph.D. (1980) in statistical dynamics of machines. He worked from 1973 to 1990 at the Tashkent State Polytechnic University (Associate Professor). Since 1991, he has been teaching at the Technion (Reliability Engineering).

p: Genady Ya. Grabarnik received his Ph.D. in Mathematics-Physics from the Institute of Mathematics, Uzbek Academy of Sciences, in 1987. He is a Researcher at the IBM T. J. Watson Research Center in Hawthorne, NY. His research interests include operator algebras, statistics, automated planning, data mining, and computer systems.

details.abstract: This study deals with simultaneous testing of two systems, one "basic" (subscript b), and the other "new" (n), both with an exponential distribution describing the times between failures. We test whether the mean TBF<sub>n</sub>/MTBF<sub>b</sub> ratio equals a given value, versus whether it is smaller than the given value. These tests yield a binomial pattern. A recursive algorithm calculates the probability of a given combination of failure numbers in the systems, permitting rapid, accurate determination of the test characteristics. The influence of truncation of Wald's Sequential Probability Ratio Test (SPRT) on its characteristics is analysed, and relationships are derived for calculating the coordinates of truncation apex (TA). A test planning methodology is presented for the most common cases

patentCitations.patentAbstract: Test characteristics are determined at vertices of a rectangle defined on a sequential probability ratio test plot of a number of failures of a new physical system versus a number of failures of a baseline physical system. Based on the test characteristics, errors of first and second order are approximated as planes. Based on the approximating, intercepts of accept and reject boundaries are estimated. Based on slopes of the planes and actual values of the errors of the first and second orders, a starting point is determined on a graph of values of an intercept of the reject boundary and values of an intercept of the accept boundary. A minimum of an operating characteristic function is determined by alternative advances, commencing at the starting point, parallel to an axis representing the accept boundary intercept and an axis representing the reject boundary intercept.

context.text: A few references to such tests can be found in the literature, mostly in the form of in-depth reviews on the subject [11]–[12][19].
The Wald Sequential Probability Ratio Test (SPRT) cannot be of infinite duration [12], but may considerably exceed the average [12], [25].

The analytical dependences between the parameters which define the decision boundaries on the one hand, and arbitrary \$\alpha\$, \$\beta\$, and the determination ratio \$d\$ on the other, are approximate [12], [26].
From the viewpoint of the average test duration, the SPRT is optimal at \$\varPhi_{0}\$, and \$\varPhi_{1}\$ [12], [35], [36], and acceptable as a basis for evaluation of the studied truncated tests.
This construction principle of the test has been termed “sequential” [12].
Approximate analytical expressions for the OC, and ASN of such tests are presented (acc. to Wald [12]).
For solving such a problem, a binomial SPRT is available, where the decisions are demarcated as straight lines (Fig. 1) with parameters dependent on \$(p_{0},\alpha)\$, and \$(p_{1},\beta)\$ [12].
\$P_{a}(\varPhi)\$ (the OC), and \$ASN_{th}(\varPhi)\$ of a non-truncated SPRT are obtainable in parametric form as per [12] where \$\alpha\$, and \$\beta\$ being the desired values for this test.

Accordingly, various types of truncation are adopted [12], [14], [15], [26], of which the following are most common for the tests under consideration (Fig. 2):

(a)
\${\rm H}_{0}\$ is rejected on reaching \$r_{nMax}\$.

(b)
\${\rm H}_{0}\$ is accepted on reaching \$r_{bMax}\$.

(c)
A diagonal (centerline) is drawn through (0,0), parallel to the SPRT boundaries; a horizontal segment of REJECT is drawn at the \$r_{nMax}\$ level until it meets the centerline, at which point a vertical segment of ACCEPT is drawn downwards.
This approach is frequently implemented [3], [12], [28].
